description:
Computer-Aided Nodule Assessment and Risk Yield (CANARY) is a novel computed tomography (CT) tool developed at Mayo Clinic (Rochester, MN) that characterizes early lung adenocarcinoma by detecting nine distinct voxel classes, representing a spectrum of lepidic to invasive growth, within an adenocarcinoma. CANARY characterization has been shown to correlate with ADC histology and patient outcomes.

 

This protocol provides basic instructions for segmentation of lung adenocarcinoma on CT imaging. CANARY has been validated in lung adenocarcinomas less than 3cm in diameter
manuscript_citation: Nakajima EC, Frankland MP, Johnson TF, Antic SL, Chen H, Chen S, Karwoski RA, Walker R, Landman BA, Clay RD, Bartholmai BJ, Rajagopalan S, Peikert T, Massion PP, Maldonado F (2018) Assessing the inter-observer variability of Computer-Aided Nodule Assessment and Risk Yield (CANARY) to characterize lung adenocarcinomas. PLoS ONE 13(6): e0198118. doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0198118
keywords: CANARY, radiomics, lung adenocarcinoma, computed tomography, CT, NSCLC
authors: Erica C. Nakajima,Ronald Karwoski,Fabien Maldonado,Srinivasan Rajagopalan,Tucker F. Johnson,Michael P. Frankland
status_info: This protocol has been validated with a cohort of 95 lung adenocarcinomas <3cm in diameter.

components.data: Scroll up and down in axial view to identify the pulmonary nodule. Scroll through the entirety of the lungs to ensure you are not missing a nodule. (Keep the CT image in “lung view”, i.e. Do not change the image view to “soft tissue” if trying to differentiate between solid and sub-solid tissue).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Scroll up and down in axial view to identify the pulmonary nodule. Scroll through the entirety of the lungs to ensure you are not missing a nodule. (Keep the CT image in “lung view”, i.e. Do not change the image view to “soft tissue” if trying to differentiate between solid and sub-solid tissue).

components.data: Click the axis tool (defined below) and place it over the nodule so that you can see it in all three views (axial, sagittal, and coronal).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Click the axis tool (defined below) and place it over the nodule so that you can see it in all three views (axial, sagittal, and coronal).

components.data: Click the nodule, and a box will be placed around it with the rest of the screen in red.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Click the nodule, and a box will be placed around it with the rest of the screen in red.

components.data: Ensure the entirety of the nodule is enclosed within the box in all three views. Adjust the box dimensions by clicking and dragging the border to the desired location.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Ensure the entirety of the nodule is enclosed within the box in all three views. Adjust the box dimensions by clicking and dragging the border to the desired location.

components.data: If the nodule abuts the pleura or mediastinal structures, exclude these tissues as much as possible from within the box. You can expand the nodule perimeter after it has been established by the software, but it can take a great deal of time to erase tissue that you do not want included in the analysis.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: If the nodule abuts the pleura or mediastinal structures, exclude these tissues as much as possible from within the box. You can expand the nodule perimeter after it has been established by the software, but it can take a great deal of time to erase tissue that you do not want included in the analysis.

components.data: The Wall function may also be used to exclude tissue from the chest wall. Draw a line along the chest wall, clicking once to create distinct points along the line. At the last point, double click to finish the line. Scroll through the CT slices that involve the lung nodule. Adjust the line by moving its distinct points to ensure that the chest wall is appropriately excluded.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The Wall function may also be used to exclude tissue from the chest wall. Draw a line along the chest wall, clicking once to create distinct points along the line. At the last point, double click to finish the line. Scroll through the CT slices that involve the lung nodule. Adjust the line by moving its distinct points to ensure that the chest wall is appropriately excluded.
Click "Get nodule mask".

components.data: A red ROI will appear around the perimeter of the nodule. (Pressing the letter “T” will toggle the mask on and off from the screen, but not permanently remove it.)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: A red ROI will appear around the perimeter of the nodule. (Pressing the letter “T” will toggle the mask on and off from the screen, but not permanently remove it.)

components.data: Scroll through the slices and adjust the mask with the tools below.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Scroll through the slices and adjust the mask with the tools below.

components.data:
Use the “Nudge” function under the REFINE tab to adjust the perimeter of the nodule.

i. Holding down the middle mouse key will enable you to change the size of the Nudge tool.

ii. If the cursor is within the mask when you begin to nudge, it will EXPAND the mask.

iii. If the cursor is outside of the mask when you begin to nudge, it will SHRINK the mask.d. The Trace function can be used to include tissue of interest into the mask. Draw a line around the tissue, connecting the start and end points of the line to the original mask.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Use the “Nudge” function under the REFINE tab to adjust the perimeter of the nodule.

i. Holding down the middle mouse key will enable you to change the size of the Nudge tool.

ii. If the cursor is within the mask when you begin to nudge, it will EXPAND the mask.

iii. If the cursor is outside of the mask when you begin to nudge, it will SHRINK the mask.d. The Trace function can be used to include tissue of interest into the mask. Draw a line around the tissue, connecting the start and end points of the line to the original mask.

components.data: Once finished with all adjustments of ROI, click "Cassify nodule".
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once finished with all adjustments of ROI, click "Cassify nodule".

components.data: Once nodule has been classified for the first time, the "edit nodule" & "delete nodule" buttons can be used to adjust the ROI.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once nodule has been classified for the first time, the "edit nodule" & "delete nodule" buttons can be used to adjust the ROI.

components.data: Camera tool: Will take a screen shot of the CT scan and import the image to the final report generated for each nodule.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Camera tool: Will take a screen shot of the CT scan and import the image to the final report generated for each nodule.

components.data: Ruler tool: measure structures using cursor.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Ruler tool: measure structures using cursor.

components.data: Note tool: Enables you to label structures with a small yellow “sticky note” using the cursor. Right click for options on using the note.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Note tool: Enables you to label structures with a small yellow “sticky note” using the cursor. Right click for options on using the note.

components.data: Axis tool: Locks axial, sagittal, and coronal views so that you can scroll through the images in a coordinated fashion.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Axis tool: Locks axial, sagittal, and coronal views so that you can scroll through the images in a coordinated fashion.

components.data: Clicking "Classify" will save the CANARY data every time in the same Excel file.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Clicking "Classify" will save the CANARY data every time in the same Excel file.

components.data: The Excel data file can be found by opening the C drive: Temp folder: CANARY-Plus folder: “CANARY-PlusTumorStats”.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The Excel data file can be found by opening the C drive: Temp folder: CANARY-Plus folder: “CANARY-PlusTumorStats”.

components.data: Data from each CT case is listed in a row.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Data from each CT case is listed in a row.

components.data: Seed, X, Y, Z columns indicate the position of the cursor when the nodule mask was set.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Seed, X, Y, Z columns indicate the position of the cursor when the nodule mask was set.

components.data: Letters V (violet), I (indigo), B (blue), G (green), Y (yellow), O (orange), R (red), C (cyan), and P (pink) represent the 9 colors shown in the “Classify nodule” analysis wheel. The numbers in these columns represent the volume (mm3) of the nodule that is assigned to each color classification.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Letters V (violet), I (indigo), B (blue), G (green), Y (yellow), O (orange), R (red), C (cyan), and P (pink) represent the 9 colors shown in the “Classify nodule” analysis wheel. The numbers in these columns represent the volume (mm3) of the nodule that is assigned to each color classification.

components.data: Ensure that the CANARY-PlusTumorStats file is closed whenever segmentation is being performed. Otherwise, new data will not import into the Excel file.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Ensure that the CANARY-PlusTumorStats file is closed whenever segmentation is being performed. Otherwise, new data will not import into the Excel file.
